sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/keyst.message: Does IPv6 address need square brackets?

The dogpile memcaced backed is very poorly documented, but based on the dogpile code and memcached source code, it seems the ipv6 syntax is a little bit different for ipv6.

Valid ipv4 configurations would be:
-<ipv4>:<port>
-inet:<ipv4>:port

Valid ipv6 configuration:
-inet6:[<ipv6>]:port

So, yes, ipv6 needs brackets, but also needs it to be preceeded by "inet6"

docker/python-builder/scripts/assemble.message: Don't we need to install runtime deps in the target image? This build image simply builds the python package which we copy out and install into the target image which won't include git?

We do need to install runtime deps in the target image - but we produce that list in the builder image and write it to /output/bindep/run.txt - so that the target image doesn't have to have bindep installed.

So if we install git before producing the list in /output/bindep/run.txt - run.txt will erroneously not list git in the packages to be installed in runtime image.

Since this is now happening before the calls to bindep - we could actually miss the case where bindep declares git is needed (like zuul) because it's installed here.

We could get fancy and handle it by splitting install_pwd into 2 functions, do the whole bindep loop before installing git then the wheel loop after installing git.

Or, we could just look at all of the bindep files and see if any of them mention git, and if so just shove it into the output packages list.

Or something else.

reference/release-naming.rst.message: I don't think that's helpful.  It is consistent with the rest of the document.
So it is. That's frustrating - a problem for another time. Thanks.

So far, having the TC decide the area in advance hasn't been too much of a problem.  Even this time, when it expanded the area, I don't recall any objections.  It's at least a collaborative decision making process; we're pretty good at those.

Yes, I agree it's weird, but so far it hasn't been contentious, while defining a formula that works everywhere is difficult (for example, Shanghai is essentially its own province).  You make a good point about potentially removing or reducing even the possibility of future contention, so that is worth considering if we stick with the current system.  I'd suggest that should be a follow-up to this change.
if we really want to accumulate names in a neutral fashion, and avoid contention, then I believe that we need to have a fixed formula for determining geographic area.
Yup, if we get to the point where it seems like this system will stick around, a follow-up is definitely the right way to incorporate this particular suggestion. Thanks!

S: Berlin vs. Berlin+Brandenburg vs. whole Germany -- we went with Berlin
T: Denver vs. whole Colorado vs. Denver–Aurora combined statistical area -- we went with whole Colorado
U: Shanghai vs. Shanghai plus all top level administrative divisions up to two hops vs. whole China -- we went with whole China

First, it's a bit weird that we don't always choose the same size area (regardless of how one defines 'size'). It's not upsetting, just weird.

Second, recalling our recent experience with U, the TC only settled, out of various possibilities, on "all of China" AFTER getting nervous about the Gwoyeu Romatzyh options. You've correctly noted that defining the area is easy in the sense that our community is good at collaborative decisions. However, defining the area is actually hard in the sense that making the decision relies on knowledge of what kinds of names the area will offer up and on feeling comfortable enough to bet that at least one of those names will be okay in terms of marketing/trademark. This can cause slowdowns in the process, throwaway work, favoritism. Maybe not always but why risk it. If we just switch to the geographic area being defined by an objective formula then we remove the risk. If it turns out that there are good names outside the formula-derived area then they can always be added by exception.

kuryr_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/test.message: Actually, this test is not checking connectivity, just that the objects are created and there is a loop for that. If TIMEOUT_PERIOD is not enough, then that value is the one you need to increase so taht loop at lines 59-67 retries during more time

The timeout you mention is for getting CRDs.
In our case you get CRDs, but SG is still not updated, so you need some additional timeout

No, but that is needed to check the connectivity as you need to wait for the security groups to be enforced. Here you are just checking the crd object creating and its information. So the problem you have is that TIMEOUT_PERIOD is 20, and perhaps you need to increase that to 30 or 60

if there is a problem with that... then it may be a bug. The kuryrnetpolicy CRD is created after the SG and SG rules. So, if the CRD is there, the SG/SG-rules should be there. This sleep should not be here. You just need to wait enough time at the whille loop at L59-L67. And if that loop finishes without finding the crd, then the assertIsNotNone should trigger the error

No... The problem you hit it later, but the sg creation is trigger after creating the NP, and then, once the kuryrnetpolicy_crd is created, the SG should have been created (as that information is there -- the sg id). The only reason waiting 120 here helps is because by the time you execute the while at linkes 59-67 it is already created. So, if this is nit enforcing that the rule is applied, and it is just checking the SG being created... you should just ensure that the loop at 59-67 iterates enough times, perhaps 30 or 60 seconds, or maybe even the same 120 that you have there, but you should not wait once the kuryr-netpolicy crd is created, so just increasing the TIMEOUT_PERIOD for something bigger than 20 should do it

@Luis, the failures we see are not in SG group creation, but in SG rules creation. From what we saw sometimes we are missing ingress and sometimes egress rules

networking_ovn/ovsdb/commands.py.message:
Hi Terry,

One thing here, I've had to modify this method here [0] to use setkey() for external_ids otherwise one command would overwrite others changes. For example:

Command 1 appends {"foo": "bar"} to external_ids

Command 2 appends {"hey": "ho"} to external_ids

With the code right now, the change committed will be {"hey": "ho"}, and the update from the first command will be lost.

It seems that ovsdbapp is doing the same [1]. I will try to work on ovsdbapp to change it as well, but would be nice if we could merge this after that is done so we don't step on each others toes here.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521476/
[1] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/158ae06bce0f56e93677f94c59f81e5e76ee1ccc/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L217
Oh my bad, my patch is actually changing the SetLSwitchPortCommand. But still applicable I guess ? Perhaps we should use setkeys() for map types anyway. What do you think ?

You're removing AddLSwitchPortCommand but leaving DelLSwitchPortCommand can be a bit confusing? I know you're leaving it to delete also the DHCP options...
Would it be better to work out another command to delete the dhcp options and call it from lsp_del in impl_idl_ovn?
What do you think?

Because ovsdbapp tries to follow ovn-nbctl as closely as possible, not networking-ovn. This particular issue I had trouble coming up with a solution that I liked. Like you said, lsp_del has to return a single Command. In my ideal world, DHCP_Options wouldn't be a root table and would automatically be deleted by ovsdb-server if the options weren't attached to a port--but I don't know enough about the usage to say whether that would be bad.

I think that for practicality leaving it as part of the DelSwitchPortCommand is easier. If we add it to lsp_del() the method would need to return a list of commands to be added to the transaction and I'm not sure if txn.add() can receive a list.

Or, if we have another command we can add then separated to the transaction as:

txn.add(del_lsp_dhcp_opts())
txn.add(lsp_del())

But still, it's kinda loosely and could be error prone.

...

@Terry, why the logic to delete the DHCP Options associated with the port wasn't carried over to ovsdbapp ?
That makes a lot of sense, kinda like a foreginkey + ondelete=cascade. That would be handy!

just a nit:

uuid is the name of a standardlib in python (import uuid), I wouldn't overwrite it here.

specs/train/neutron-api-versioning.rst.message: Better wording: "This spec proposes a new versioning scheme for the neutron API"
nit: Neutron (and it applies to all other occurrences in this document)
nit: feature
decremental - as in removing things one at a time?  Or did you mean incremental?
extensions
same here

It seems to me we have two problems:

1) the current way of providing api discoveribility is cumbersome for small changes (i.e. shim extensions)

2) we do not have an established way of making backwards incompatible changes

I guess we are addressing both here. It may make sense to state them separately.
nitty nit: this dot is not needed probably
By "it" I think you mean "this proposal"; it would probably be clearer to say so.

Since we're about to change the version discovery mechanism itself we need to make that difference discoverable. How do we do that? Do we introduce API major version 3.0?

I see this is discussed below. Will continue there.
*API (capitalize the "i")
In order to do this we need to introduce an extension for the core part of the API. Random name ideas for it: 'neutron', 'core', 'neutron-core'

Is the core Neutron API considered just another extension, and so the umbrella Neutron API version would be calculated based on revisions in core + all extensions?  Or would the neutron API be the sum of the versions of all extensions plus a manual bump for core api changes?

Another consideration: What if I am a customer that doesn't use DVR but we bump the version of the DVR extension, which bumps the version of the Neutron API in general.  I then have a version bump that signifies nothing for me.  Or is the version autocalculated locally to each cloud?

Last question: if we have discoverable versions for all extensions as well as of the core API functionality, then does an umbrella API version really get us anything?

I agree with Ryan here. We should avoid providing "umbrella API version" which would be calculated somehow (how exactly?). We should IMO simply limit number of extensions for max one extension per service plugin and each of those extensions should have own version.

Perhaps, but in practice I don't think we've changed the neutron core API since Juno (perhaps earlier than that). Because of this extension craze, what you really have is a static neutron core API, with API extensions that need versioning. The way I see the world is with a core neutron plugin API that just sits at version 2 and an ecosystem of versioned extensions, each of which has a simple version that is incremented with every change to the extension.

I don't see the use for an umbrella API version, it's too complex. In my mind this doesn't mean we stop adding extensions, I just see us simply see us using simple versioning to provide discoverability of iterations on a given extension rather than creating an extension descriptor for every iteration on an existing extensions.
*are
as mentioned above, IMHO we shouldn't have one "main" API version which would depend on any extensions.
That aligns with traditional SemVer nicely

Using versions lesser than 1.0 sounds really good for experiments made from scratch. It won't really work though is someone wants to experiment with the further development of an extension already at version greater than 1.0 (e.g. 2.3).

In this scheme that is going to need a new extension like this:

foo 2.3
foo-experimental 0.9

Where foo-experimental semantically overrides foo. This is not necessarily bad, I just want to call the attention to it.

I'm not sure if we should allow to merge something like that. If "foo-experimental" is going to change API provided by "foo" already, that means that "foo" should be changed instead of adding new extension :)

Why? What do we gain by treating out-of-tree extensions special?

Unless we have some clear gain I'd argue to treat them just like in-tree extensions.
nit: The word 'whole' is unnecessary here.
regardless of whether
what is exactly goal of such version? will it tell anything to users?
technically speaking we will have to add "version" attribute to extension resource. So we will need new extension for that ;D
*corresponding
Noting for the record: In the PTG discussion we killed the microversion concept.

Extending the record: Microversions enable a client to choose between multiple API syntaxes and behaviors whose implementations must concurrently live in the server-side code base. That is the complexity we want to avoid.

Instead we preferred a versioning that describes what to expect from the API, but does *not* provide choices of multiple API syntax and behavior. That is also in-line with the current extension behavior where you cannot select which extensions you want as a client.

I think we need to examine what value an "API version as a whole" gives us when you can get a list like:

extension      version
-----------    -------
neutron-core    2.11
qos             1.5
tag             1.0
networking-ovn  3.6
etc.

I don't see a reason to provide an aggregate API version other than the whole extension map itself. Actually it would make the life of out-of-tree plugin maintainers quite hard (assuming they can have non-experimental extensions).
I agree here, IMO there is no need to provide such "main API version"
Isn't this something like micro versioning which is e.g. in nova? I think that we agreed in Denver that we shouldn't do it this way.
I wonder if each plugin should be forced to explicitly declare versions rather than assuming a default. It's not that much work to attach a version number. Just a thought.....

+1

Or if we want to have a default, make it a version number that's experimental (<1.0).
nit: version
I think this was all superceded when we junked microversion support.
Probably unnecessary, since the versions are now for discovery not validation.
+1 Unless we want to completely and deeply revamp our version discovery (for example via HTTP content negotiation so we'd have versions in each request and response) this is unnecessary.
I agree, start with simple versioning.

I think we need to contemplate this deeply.  Incrementing the API major version imposes a non-trivial load on anything that has integrated with Neutron.  Look at how long and difficult the battle Keystone had to get version 3 everywhere was.  I don't think this is a decision to make lightly, and if it is possible to implement this while still remaining within "Networking API v2.0" I think we should.

Yes, a 'versioned-extensions' extension would tell well-maintained clients they can use the versioned extensions. But what do we do with legacy (long-time unchanged) clients? We cannot expect them to check that the 'versioned-extensions' extension is *not* present, right? They will keep looking at the unversioned extension list (which we don't plan to maintain after this spec I think) and assume nothing changed. When in fact we will introduce changes to the API. At some point in the future we will break them - silently.

So ironic, LOL! A shim extension that helps is rid ourselves of shim extensions :)

I'm laughing, but also seriously contemplating this. It's actually not a bad idea.
I know that this is funny but we can add new extension to make new behaviour discoverable ;)

We can only avoid going to v3 if we make up a mechanism that allows our clients to discover the change in how extension discovery works. We can easily add something new that returns the versioned extension map. But what do we do with old and not updated clients looking at the old extension list which will not change anymore after this spec while the actual API behavior will change? Can we do that without supporting v2.0 and v3.0 concurrently? If we do that we likely want to freeze v2.0 and start with v3.0 having the same functionality than v2.0 but different extension discovery.

An alternative to avoid v3 could be to only address the problem of shim extensions. I can imagine a change so after it a new shim extension would need only a new constant entry in a list - so creating shim extensions would be easy. But that will never solve the problem of correcting API mistakes.

I agree this needs a lot of thought before we charge ahead with neutron v3. In my opinion, the introduction of a neutron v3 API is where we try to make things like routed networks and other resources more clean re-thinking what they mean and how they relate to each other. In other words, I would not want to move to a version 3 of the API unless we can go back to the drawing board with the neutron resource model. I'm not yet convinced extension versioning forces us to re-think the entire neutron resource model, so I'm not in favor of this if it can be avoided.
shouldn't be "API extension's version" here?

I don't agree with this assertion, I don't think it's that painful to group and collapse related extensions, then begin versioning them and forcing clients to be aware of the versioning. In the abstract I don't see this approach as being that  different than what we do today with shim extensions. Instead of adding a shim and making clients aware of it, we would simply increment a simple version and make clients aware of the new version.
That's true. I think the harder question is what do you do legacy clients?

question: There is a case where two neutron servers process two updates on a same resources (let's call revision number 5 and 6) and the first process (for revision number 5) can completes later. This is a good question. In OVN we rely on a special OVSDB command and also in the "verify()" action for the transaction to abort transactions if it has a lower revision_number compared to what is already committed in the OVSDB. Please take a look at [0] for more info.

For other SBIs that does not support anything like that, I believe the only solution is to have a lock based on the resource UUID (so it will be per resource instead of a global thing) that would link these two transactions (the one to update the SBI and the one updating the revision numbers).

Added this as part of the arguments.

Good point, my take on this is:

Neutron already has a concurrent design, multiple neutron-servers are already being spawned to handle things in parallel. The approach proposed in this spec make use of that design where in the journaling the neutron-serves are only used to queue up changes to be later processed by the journal threads.

That makes things a bit more complicated, for example, how many journal threads would be necessary to process the output of all the API workers in a reasonable time ?

If the answer is > 1 worker, then we need to introduce some sort of serialization/dependency check for that queue of changes to make sure that things like a port that belongs to certain network is only created after that network has already been created.

The approach proposed in this spec this is not a problem because by the time the API request to create the network returns, the SBI already will have that network created in it (or the driver will have the confirmation that the request to create that network in the SBI succeeded and is being processed), things happens more synchronously.

Also in the journaling, the number of journal threads should also be relative to the size of the deployment. Maybe 1 journal thread is enough if you have 10 Neutron API workers, but what if you have 100 Neutron API workers ?

From the Neutron driver perspective I don't think that it can calculate that since it won't have a enough view of the deployment and its size. This logic would need to be placed on a layer above, such as the deployment tool (e.g TripleO) and we would need to come up with a methodology to determine this journal thread/API worker(s) ratio number.

Testing the API response time also can be misleading with the journaling approach since the neutron-servers are just queuing things up and and returning. The API response time will look faster but we will need custom tools to be able to validate the real performance of the journal [0] (from the moment that the API accepts the request until the change is pick by a journal thread and sent to the SBI). Tools like Rally or Browbeat might have a problem validating the real performance of the requests as-is.

These are some of the problems I see with the journaling and its journal threads which does not affected the proposed approach.

The OVSDB lock is still valid and in networking-ovn we intend to still use it for the database inconsistency problem. Because with the OVSDB lock we guarantee that only one periodic task fixing the database inconsistencies is running at a time in the cluster. And that's enough, it hasn't been a bottleneck for us.

Hi Ryan,

I think they author of the spec could clarify this a little more, but yes, the inconsistencies are detected and fixed periodically. In networking-ovn we run the "maintenance task" every 5 minutes. So the idea of this mechanism is to get an eventual consistency.

It should be a lightweight operation, since the inconsistencies are detected by doing a JOIN comparison between the Neutron's standardattribute table and the cache table for the SBI (ovn_revision_numbers table, in OVN).

When I was creating it in networking-ovn, I wrote a small blog post with some reasoning: http://lucasgom.es/posts/neutron_ovn_database_consistency.html

Maybe that help clarify some aspects of it (and we should put those in the spec too).

what kind of arguments are expected? resource_type?
standardattribute is used for almost all resources and a driver covers subset of them, so I think resource_type(s) is required.

Looking at the implementation example section, it seems we need filtering based on arguments. Some example here would be nice.

In networking-ovn, we use a join to match the resources by their standard attribute id [0].

In SQL it will be something like:

"SELECT ovn_revision_numbers.standard_attr_id, ovn_revision_numbers.resource_uuid, ovn_revision_numbers.resource_type, ovn_revision_numbers.revision_number, standardattributes.revision_number AS neutron_revision_number FROM ovn_revision_numbers INNER JOIN standardattributes ON ovn_revision_numbers.standard_attr_id=standardattributes.id;"

We only need to look at the cache table for resources with their standard_attribute_id set to NULL. Because, when the resource is deleted from Neutron, it will cascade to the cache table setting the "standard_attr_id" column to NULL (ONDELETE=SET NULL).

A similar topic has been brought up during on the neutron qos work: SR-IOV vifs do not support ingress bw limitation, and the question was what could be exposed to the user.  This issue is similar to the one here, but distinct in the sense that (a) there is an unresolvable reason for the heterogeneousness in capabilities, and (b) it's not per-driver but per-vif type (vifs of different types can be present on a Network).

Today the API is already the backend contract, everything that is exposed through the API should be implemented, though a backend may choose to partially implement a feature and that's when the problems occur.

So the problem is real, however I am not sure this proposal is viable or addressing the problem in a way that is maintainable long term so that there is not a constant misalignment between what a driver can actually do and what the capabilities API is saying the driver is supposed to do.

I agree that "everything that is exposed through the API should be implemented" but with SFC we will definitely run into partially implemented features or missing features, especially with the bipolarity between "legacy" SC and "modern" SFC, i.e. essentially when NSH comes into play.

What are the main objections against having all desirable features in the networking-sfc API and, depending on the backend, return insucess if an unsupported feature was requested?

I'm not advocating for squeezing additional features from drivers by bypassing or exploiting the API in some way, I'm saying the API would limit the available features - and if some backend can't do it, well they can't do it, and the request isn't fulfilled.

I'm particularly concerned about the synchronization issue. If we have a bunch of drivers for different backends and all but one of the backends supports a new feature, do we hold off on adding the new feature to the API until the last backend supports it (which might never happen)?

Or do we implement a new feature in the API when even just one backend provides that feature and just let the API call fail if any other backend is used?

The idea here is to allow us to introduce new features to the API when we have at least one viable implementation, but to provide the tenant with an abstract way to verify whether the current driver can support it (but without the tenant having to know exactly what backend is in use and what its capabilities are.)

If we really have to go down this path (which can be debated in itself), I believe you would have to expose the capabilities of all the drivers enabled on a server, and indicate which is the default driver.

I still think "driver" is wrong here. We want to group capabilities by the logical structure of the API, not by the implementation details of various drivers. The tenant's interest in calling this API is to tell them what the rest of the API will let them do. The details of the driver should be unimportant to the tenant other than to inform them whether it has the capability to handle the API calls that their program wants to make.

This is one of the key question: under which condition does it add value ? what is the cost/benefit ratio?

The cost is two-fold:
- designing & implementing this capability framework
- having the API leverage it

If the framework is mostly used by a client to do "if feature X is available then do (something depending on X) else fail", then I would argue that the value is reduced.

I would argue that such a framework would only add value for cases where the API client can choose an alternative solution if feature X happens to not be available: e.g. he could choose another driver having feature X, or it can choose to reach its goal by relying on another feature than feature X.  But I'm not sure these case are frequent enough.

The complexity of client-side automation/orchestration code leveraging these capabilities could end up being quite high. For instance think about a Heat template that would do A if feature X is available and B if not (with B being something else than 'fail').

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
According to [1], this method calculates "the IP availability stats on a per subnet basis". What this method is doing is:
1) "_generate_subnet_total_ips_dict"
- Retrieving the subnets of the network
- Retrieving the IP allocation pools
- Calculating the total number of IPs in the subnets according to the IP allocation pools

2) "_build_network_used_ip_query"
- Retrieving the used IPs on this network

3) Returning both sets assembled


I don't see where this logic is wrong. This method is returning the IP availability for the current IP allocation pools. If, as you mention [2], the pool is reduced, the function should return the IPs allocated *inside* this pools and the free ones.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/674723/4/neutron/db/network_ip_availability_db.py@71

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/674723/4/neutron/tests/unit/extensions/test_network_ip_availability.py@425
Sorry but I don't understand this. Can you explain what does it mean??

The current algorithm is

1. If 10 IPs have been used, the address pool is reduced and only contains only 2 IPs. 10 IPs have been used and a total of 2 IPs will be returned from current interface.

2. If 10 IP has been used, delete all address pool. the total of IPs is the number of cidr. But you can't create a port at this time.

neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall.message:
Although this normal action should deliver the packet only into the ofport, we should be more restrictive and keep the original "output" action.

As commented in [1], only changes in ARP and DHCP are enough to learn the VMs src mac addresses.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1732067/comments/10

I got it. Looks reasonable.
But as I understand then the original issue with packets flooding will depend on internals of guest configuration, or, for example, fdb flushing/ovs-vswitchd restart.

Fdb entry is removed after 300s (an ovs-vswitchd timeout) if there is no packets to/from a VM during 300 seconds.

If assume a client/the VM knows each other mac address then a new client <-> VM communication after 300s will again cause a packets flooding.

So, I am not sure the normal action restriction only in ARP and DHCP will be enough to avoid the VM's packets flooding.

Hi, as my understanding, FDB entry in br-int will be updated only if guest send ARP if we only add normal action for ARP flow, same for DHCP.
We'd better not depend on guest ARP settings. 
You can use ping to test this. After FDB entry in br-int deleted after timeout, response ICMP will flood.
Good point. But ARP will be sent when cache entry expires.

I've applied the patch on my stand and it broke connectivity with VMs that are plugged into flat network.

The 'normal' action floods packets only to ovs ports witch tags are matched to the current flow vlan tag or port is trunk.

In the TRANSIENT_TABLE a vlan tag is stripped (`strip_vlan` action in `initialize_port_flows` method)

So, looks like it's the reason why I lost connectivity with my VM: VM is plugged to an access port but 'normal' action floods packet only to ovs trunk ports (because a vlan tag is stripped in the TRANSIENT_TABLE for ingress traffic)


For example,
'fa:16:3e:f9:33:e7' is a VM mac address;
'tapf62aaee9-6e' is the VM's tap interface on the node.
'br-enp5s0f0' is an external network bridge;
'int-br-enp5s0f0' is a patch port for the external bridge in br-int

Note to self:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631244/46/nova/compute/manager.py@2627

The event only gets routed to the compute if instance.host is set and that only happens upon a successful instance_claim during the build process:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/757fc03b78d542e7262343b65eacea02ce11dd04/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L170

So if by chance the event comes before the instance.host is set the compute won't get the event, but that should be OK because it sounds like the compute code is going to call back to cyborg to ask if it was already done - find that it is (otherwise it wouldn't have sent the event) - and just proceed.
That's correct, and we discussed this on the cyborg patch, specifically about what the 422 should mean to cyborg if indeed it sends the event before scheduling and host claim happens.

But out of curiosity, why are we bothering to allow this? Is it in case there are nested wait_for_instance_event contexts?
Since this is just passing through, I've added the setification below where we process the result (slightly differently in the next PS for simplicity).
Sorry, to clarify: it needs to be a *list-like* thing to handle multiple events and test for membership. It *can* be a set if it matters to you, it just doesn't to the code.

Sure, it really needs to anything we can test for membership in. We could set()ify it here if we wanted to to strip dupes, but it doesn't matter.

It needs to be a list because the whole thing is multi-event based. If you have three neutron ports, you need to listen for all three at once. If you poll and find one is already wired up but the other two are not, you want to bail and say "don't worry about port2 but have port1 and port3 still wait.

Doesn't this mean that, if you call exit_wait_early(), we'll *skip* everything after that in your context manager? That very well may be a good thing and what the caller wants, but it should definitely be called out in the docstring.

As discussed earlier, I specifically want an exception here because I do not want you to be able to signal events to skip before you run some code. The whole point of the existing mechanism is that you prepare...do something to trigger the events...exit and wait. nova/tests/unit/compute/test_virtapi.py.message: This is kind of an odd construct; why wouldn't we use `with mock.patch.object` instead?

What is odd? Using a closure within a test to get access to self? It's very common in our tests, and definitely here (see the several methods for testing the waiter above. In general, any time I have more than one thing to patch I prefer the closure pattern instead of the context manager because with..with..code gets hard to read. Also, python2 can't have a multi-line with statement (not sure about python3), so your context manager usage always had to be small, hence the closure pattern.

tbc, you're doing this again on purpose without mocking the waiter ... to prove that it still completes? Why would it not?

If this isn't a typo, I would suggest you take the mock decorator off of do_test and just define it as a regular method, so then you can invoke it once under a `with mock.patch.object` and once bare.

I'm doing it without mocking out the waiter which gives us the default behavior of completing the events as the regular code does. It works when mocked above because we're exiting early. If we didn't, it would raise an error about the event not being completed (see the fakes at the top of this file).
Given the way the code is shaped, IMO we should have a test that waits for multiple events, calls exit_wait_early for a subset of them, and proves that we still waited for the others.
I'm changing this test to be much more straightforward and less obscure, which I think will help.
Oh, sorry, I didn't notice 'baz' (as opposed to 'bar'). Might make that more visually obvious (but it's really my fault).

Well, this does to be clear, it's just that I don't have the baz one in there so it never does anything for that one but does complete the bar one we waited for. But yeah, I will put more assertions here in line with the first test in this series that checks that we called everything in the fake.

So my point: none of this code is reached. And you should put a self.fail() here to prove it.

then this raise the events as an excpetion.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695985/4/nova/compute/manager.py@435

which will cause the context manager resume execution
